docs.lead_paragraph: Donating breast milk should be more like donating blood.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Elizabeth Currid-Halkett calls on women who are able to produce excess breast milk and who have the time and resources to donate their milk to milk banks; suggests ways to encourage breast milk donation, such as provision of free breast pumps and storage banks by philanthropic organizations, as well as public-awareness campaigns about milk donation.
docs.snippet: Donating breast milk should be more like donating blood.

docs.lead_paragraph: When good news of solid job growth at both the national level and in states is a conservative nightmare.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column examines why conservatives and Republicans are skeptical about job growth and economic recovery that is occurring nationally and in state of California; posits that job growth in wake of passage of Affordable Care Act directly conflicts with Republican predictions of economic doom, and that California's growth despite its resistance to tax-cutting and deregulation threatens basis of conservative fiscal thought.
docs.snippet: When good news of solid job growth at both the national level and in states is a conservative nightmare.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: In a significant bipartisan move backed by President Obama, the House agreed on changing the formula for doctors’ fees and extending the Children’s Health Insurance Program.

headline.main: House Approves Bill on Changes to Medicare
headline.print_headline: House Approves Bill on Changes to Medicare

docs.abstract: House votes 392 to 37 to approve sweeping changes to Medicare that would establish new formula for paying doctors, increase some premiums, and extend popular children's health insurance program; vote represents most significant bipartisan policy legislation in House since Republicans regained majority in 2011.
docs.snippet: In a significant bipartisan move backed by President Obama, the House agreed on changing the formula for doctors’ fees and extending the Children’s Health Insurance Program.

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: For the past month, the name most associated with venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is former partner Ellen Pao, who took the firm to trial for gender discrimination and retaliation.

headline.main: Amid Trial, Kleiner Perkins Recruits Next Generation of Partners

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Senate on Thursday launched a marathon session that will end with a vote on a budget plan after lawmakers weigh in on dozens of amendments that are likely to have more effect on campaign ads in 2016 than the final spending plan.

headline.main: Senate Tries to Score Political Points on Way to Budget Vote
headline.print_headline: Senate Tries to Score Political Points on Way to Budget Vote

docs.snippet: The U.S. Senate on Thursday launched a marathon session that will end with a vote on a budget plan after lawmakers weigh in on dozens of amendments that are likely to have more effect on campaign ads in 2016 than the final spending plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has asked for a drastic cutback of an ambitious health care plan after cost estimates came in at $18.5 billion over five years, several government sources said, delaying a promise made in his election manifesto.

headline.main: Exclusive: Modi Government Puts Brakes on India's Universal Health Plan
headline.print_headline: Exclusive: Modi Government Puts Brakes on India's Universal Health Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. House of Representatives on Thursday overwhelmingly approved a bill to permanently repair the formula for reimbursing Medicare physicians, marking a rare bipartisan achievement and sending the issue next to the Senate.

headline.main: U.S. House Okays Bipartisan Bill to Fix Medicare Doctor Payments
headline.print_headline: U.S. House Okays Bipartisan Bill to Fix Medicare Doctor Payments

docs.snippet: The U.S. House of Representatives on Thursday overwhelmingly approved a bill to permanently repair the formula for reimbursing Medicare physicians, marking a rare bipartisan achievement and sending the issue next to the Senate.
